entry.title: Threshold Exclusive: Simmy Aircraft Launches First Aircraft Project - The DA42 With Exclusive Shots

By participating in the production of some of our favorite aircraft, we can be hopeful to see similar qualities in their products. Their early work in progress images show an already stunning strong start, Simmy's has provided Threshold with a fresh set of new images to feature: The team have stated that their primary goal is to provide a product that can be utilized in a manner that aids training. Itâs no secret the DA42 is widely used across the world as a modern twin engine training option, making this a great aircraft to have virtualized, especially considering so many students are actively training on it. With this in mind, the team have expressed that in conjunction to creating a visually immaculate model, the accuracy of flight behaviors and system depth, are at the forefront of their priorities.Â Looking at the current team of two, it is interesting to note that both members are actively training. entry.title: VerticalSim Releases Syracuse for X-Plane 11
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. VerticalSim has released the visual rendition of Syracuse Airport (KSYR) for X-Plane 11 just 3 months after the initial release of Boise Airport for the same client. The developerâs scenery style has finally reached the Empire State. Syracuse Airport is locate near the city of Syracuse, New York. After land was purchased in 1928, a small airfield was constructed to service airmail carriers. After World War 2, the Army Air Corps leased the local bomber base near the small airfield, which then further transformed into the Clarence E. Hancock Airport in 1949. At the time of opening, the airport had four airlines basing routes in and out of the airfield, which included but are not limited to, American Airlines and Mohawk Airlines. Today, the airport receives both passenger and cargo operations. This visual rendition offers many qualities that VerticalSim has made standard in all of its releases. SAM Jetway support and animated vehicle traffic have also been added to enhance the userâs experience. Lastly, taxi routes are available for AI Traffic addons. entry.title: MK-STUDIOS Releases Rome-Fiumicino For MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. The development teams at MK-STUDIOS have released their visual rendition of Rome-Fiumicino International Airport (LIRF) for Microsoft Flight Simulator. This release brings the developerâs quality and attention to detail to the Mediterranean airport. To some, this airport is also known as the Leonardo Da Vinci International Airport, opening its doors in 1961. With 2 runways operating upon opening, this airport was to help alleviate passenger traffic from the smaller Rome Ciampino Airport after the 1960 Rome Olympics. The airport later built a third runway when Alitalia Airlines built its main hub within the same decade. Today, the airport is ranked the 11th busiest airport in Europe, servicing 43.5 million passengers in 2019 (pre-pandemic), and services the new Italian carrier, ITA Airways as of late 2021. entry.title: VATSIM Cross the Pond Westbound Airports Announced
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. After originally opening up voting earlier this month, the Virtual Air Traffic Simulation Network, better known as VATSIM, has revealed the airports set to be used for this year's Cross the Pond (CTP) Westbound event. This year, it will take place on April 2nd. For those unaware, Cross the Pond is an extremely popular event held annually on the network which allows users to fly across the Atlantic with full ATC coverage and realistic procedures. Not only does this event generate a lot of excitement within the community, but it typically sees an incredible amount of traffic, making it one of the busiest events on the network. Ranging from Munich Airport (EDDM) to Barbados (TBPB), the community has voted on a multitude of different departure and arrival aerodromes, which are viewable in the picture below. It should be noted, however, that users will need to book a CTP slot to ensure participation in this event without delays. However, users are able to take part in the event without booking a slot, but delays should be expected. For further information make sure to check out the VATSIM Cross the Pond website. As well, Threshold will make sure to keep you updated once the bookings for the event open.

entry.title: Laminar Research Addresses Wake Turbulence in X-Plane 12
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. Phillip from Laminar Research addressed wake turbulence in the upcoming X-Plane 12 Flight Simulator. Involving both player aircraft and AI aircraft and its correlation with the simulator physics and aerodynamics. AI Traffic After a brief introduction about wake turbulence, Phillip addresses the wake turbulence that is left by AI aircraft. All AI aircraft will leave the correct wake turbulence that corresponds to its aircraft, and is calculated properly with the vortex that is created by the wing of the aircraft. Same will apply for user aircraft. Phillip then goes on to say: Online Traffic, 3rd Party Plugins, and Live Traffic Further on, Phillip addresses wake turbulence left by online network aircraft, live traffic, and other 3rd party plugins. With the correct data through an ADS-B exchange, X-Plane will calculate the best effects to aircraft weight, wing area, and wingspan through the data the plugin provides. Current XP11 traffic plugins are compatible with the wake turbulence and will be a base function in XP12. Thatâs it for todayâs update, but Threshold will be sure to keep you up to date with any further X-Plane 12 development updates.

entry.title: Just Flight Further Previews MSFS BAe 146
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Just Flight has posted more previews of their upcoming BAe 146 for MSFS2020. The news comes in light of their subsequent aircraft developments, such as the newly announced 757, collaboration with DCDesigns, and In-House Fokker F28. The team mentions in their Facebook post that more news will be delivered in the imminent future and that "release time draws closer." The following screenshots showcase the aircraft partaking in a test flight from Southampton to Bournemouth. For those who are unaware, the British Aerospace 146, also known as the BAe 146, is a short-haul regional airliner developed by British Aerospace. Containing four turbofan engines, as well as a T-tail, the "Jumbolino" garners its reputation from its quirky design features. Over 380 units were built from 1978-to 2001, primarily serving European operators such as CityJet and Swiss. The aircraft was delivered under the name "Avro RJ" after 1992, shipping with upgraded avionics and more powerful engines. In the current world, few Avro RJs remain, some serve middle eastern carriers, and some serve as "off the grid" transporters as the aircraft contains gravel landing abilities. Just Flight did not share any additional information regarding the BAe 146's development, but keep an eye out shortly as the team admitted that there's a new development update around the corner.
